images.title: Title of Image 1
images.description: I traveled with my family to Big Sur. We walked along this beach in the early morning. This natural rock formation looked like a door to Poseidon’s lair. I loved the idea that you might walk through it an end up in a totally other world. It felt like an invitation to enter into the unknown, to leave the land of the words and clear intentions and to enter the submerged totality of the senses. Watercolor on paper. 18 in x 24 in
images.media: Watercolor on paper. 18 in x 24 in

images.title: Title of Image 3
images.description: What is the painting equivalent of a double exposure? Or A piece of music that is stubbornly in two keys at once. Or that braided split between story and discourse... what you say and how you say it... can a painting be two things at once? Watercolor on paper. 18 in x 24 in
images.media: Watercolor on paper. 18 in x 24 in

images.title: Title of Image 3
images.description: Leaf by leaf, I spent that summer painting this view from inside San Francisco's Conservatory of Flowers. This was a pandemic painting. And somehow the brilliant world inside the hothouse seemed to connect to our paradise and our prision of shared isolation. Famlies grew closer. We learned to look closely at our surroundings. Watercolor on paper. 18 in x 24 in
images.media: Watercolor on paper. 18 in x 24 in

images.title: Title of Image 1
images.description: This painting took 25 months to complete. I went blind in one eye and it took over a year for my sight to recover. My vision is now normal, but during that time I had a hard time controlling the tip of my brush so that it might be correctly located in space. Also my sense of color was off, as my blood-filled eye changed the tint of everything. But I did not give up, and wanted to show my kids (and myself) that the answer was to keep going.
images.media: Oil on wood. 18 in x 24 in

images.title: Title of Image 2
images.description: Oil on Linen. I traveled with my father to a ghost town in Oregon. It's not on any map, but instead hidden in the middle of a ranch. We went to the ranch, knocked on the door and explained our intentions, and then went to the site. There is a series of buildings on the site, this is the largest, it is a former hotel.
images.media: Oil on Linen. 48 in x 48 in

images.title: Title of Image 2

images.title: Title of Image 2
images.description: Oil on Linen. I traveled with my father to a ghost town in Oregon. It's not on any map, but instead hidden in the middle of a ranch. We went to the ranch, knocked on the door and explained our intentions, and then went to the site. This collapsed house is across the road from the Hotel.
images.media: Oil on Linen. 48 in x 48 in

images.title: Title of Image 2
images.description: Oil on gessoed wood. My father and I tracked wild mustangs on 1.5 million acres of BLM land to find this running bachelor. Eventually he led us to the rest of the group. What an unforgettable time filming and then painting these marvelous Kiger mustangs.
images.media: Oil on Linen. 48 in x 48 in

images.title: Title of Image 2
images.description: Abstraction that later set the stage for the visual vocabulary of HOMEWARD, a ballet with Benjamin Millepied and Bryce Dessner.
images.media: Colored pencil on paper. 12 in x 12 in

images.title: Title of Image 6
images.description: This is a watercolor sketch of an AR project to bring dance to Paris. The idea is that you'd look up and see dancers the size of demigods performing across the Parisian skyline. Watercolor on paper. 18 in x 24 in
images.media: Watercolor on paper. 18 in x 24 in

images.title: Title of Image 2
images.description: Watercolor + Digital sketch for an AR dance project
images.media: Oil on Linen. 48 in x 48 in

images.title: Title of Image 3
images.description: View of Venice of The Bridge of Sighs. That terrible walk from judgement to punishment. We went as a family and quite enjoyed walking that same path. And in that moment, awaiting your fate, those stolen glimpses through the window... caught moments of the poignancy of life. Watercolor on paper. 18 in x 24 in
images.media: Watercolor on paper. 18 in x 24 in

images.title: Title of Image 2
images.description: This is a lead-holder known as the Fixpencil. It is without a doubt my favorite way to work with lead. Inside the barrel is a 3mm tube of graphite available in a dark 6B softness that pulls midnight from noon and drains the ocean’s depths into a teacup. Hidden inside the endcap is a sharpener. The lead is advanced with a push-activated clutch system. Here I’ve painted a small portrait of the Fixpencil, but instead of using it to draw itself (which felt too on the nose). I’ve rendered it in watercolor using a narrow mongoose-haired brush. Somehow the blue watercolor was a better match for the myth that surrounds this particular writing tool.
images.media: Watercolor on paper. 18 in x 24 in

images.title: Title of Image 2
images.description: Oil on gessoed paper. What does our phone see when we touch the glass? You can just make out a subtle flattening and discoloration in my finger prints as they press against the unseen surface.
images.media: Oil on Linen. 48 in x 48 in

images.title: Title of Image 2
images.description: Watercolor on paper. Friends and Stangers. It wasn't Halloween, just a normal day in the Haight. These two were walking down the street and I asked to take a picture.
images.media: Oil on Linen. 48 in x 48 in

images.title: Title of Image 2
images.description: Four oil paintings on linen of the same subject. At first glance, they all look the same. But look again and you'll see I made slight adjustments for each still life. I quite like seeing them all together, the group feels like a deconstructed animation.
images.media: Oil on Linen. 48 in x 48 in

images.title: Title of Image 2
images.description: Watercolor on paper. My father's working rope, made from rawhide, with a brass honda.
images.media: Oil on Linen. 48 in x 48 in

images.title: Title of Image 2
images.description: Oil on linen. Painting of a rope, done in a looser style. Where the shadows and the subject almost echo Bryce Marden's wodnerful abstractions.
images.media: Oil on Linen. 48 in x 48 in

images.title: Title of Image 2
images.description: Oil on linen. Painting from imagination. All the forms seem possible, but the forces at work could not be applied at the same time. My hope was to create a painting that existed across time, so that you'd imagine different parts of it occurring at different moments. This is not a snapshot or a freezeframe, but a network of tensions that resolve or evolve over time.
images.media: Oil on Linen. 48 in x 48 in

images.title: Title of Image 2
images.description: Oil on gessoed paper. This dead bird was visible from my window. Look closely and you'll see a fly on its beak.
images.media: Oil on paper. 18 in x 24 in
